description:
## vLLM

This dashboard provides observability for your vLLM deployments with the vLLM Integration.

It shows information about how many tokens your model is generating per second as well as exposing low-level details such as GPU/CPU usage and Python memory management.

## Useful Links
- [vLLM Integration ↗](https://docs.datadoghq.com/integrations/vllm)
- [vLLM Metrics ↗](https://docs.vllm.ai/en/latest/serving/metrics.html)
- [vLLM Documentation ↗](https://docs.vllm.ai/en/stable/)
title: vLLM Overview

definition.content:
## vLLM

This dashboard provides observability for your vLLM deployments with the vLLM Integration.

It shows information about how many tokens your model is generating per second as well as exposing low-level details such as GPU/CPU usage and Python memory management.

Here you can see an overview of your vLLM of your system activity and any vLLM alerts. The service checks on the left indicates the health of your vLLM environment, while the ones on the right report on the Readiness of various vllm Dependencies.

Here you can see how vLLM is performing its main task: generating text.

This ranges from how long an entire request takes to how long it takes to break it down into time spent on each token.
And from time spent preparing to generate the first token to how many tokens your models produce after they get going.
As vLLM does its job it is important that it does not overload your operating system. Check that you are not exceeding the open file descriptor maximum. Inspect virtual and resident memory usage.

definition.title: Open File Descriptors over Maximum File Descriptors

definition.content: The GPU is the workhorse of vLLM. It is also expensive to run. See here how many requests your GPU is running and how you are taking advantage of its caching mechanisms.
You can save on some infrastructure costs by doing some of the work on CPUs instead of GPUs. In this section, you can see how much of your vLLM load ends up being sent to the CPU for processing.

This section helps explore how vLLM uses memory. vLLM runs in Python, a language with a garbage collector to reclaim memory. This garbage collector collects objects in generations. You can see how each generation of objects gets processed.
